content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a nice reverse puzzle that players could approach in a number of ways

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Quite easy, geometrical approach

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice reverse clash that can be approached in a few ways, so it's possible to solve it because you recognise the problem or simply by playing around with a formula until it works.

This is nice, pretty easy to hack your way to a solution even if you can't remember the formula naturally.

Couple of edits I think would make it more suitable as a Reverse clash:
1. Put the "n  ≥ 3" from the statement (which won't be seen) into the stub generator so that clashers get this information in the clash:
read N:int
write answer

STATEMENT
n  ≥ 3

2. The hardest part about this clash for a lot of coders is going to end up being the formatting rather than the actual coding and pattern-finding. 
If you have a statement (fastest/shortest modes) then you can just explain the rules (e.g. print with 2 dp, but remove leading zeroes such that 6.00 -> 6.
But in Reverse mode you can't explain it so it's a bit hard. Especially since it's not clear from your test cases exactly what the rule is. It could be the example above, or another rule (e.g. print with 2 dp if float, else print as integer). The two examples would differ on how to print "17.40" vs "17.4", but your solution specifies it would be "17.40"... I think it would be kinder to clashers if you just simplify it so that all answers are with 2 decimal places.

I actually solved it assuming it should format "17.40" as "17.4", so I used sprintf formatting "%g" % ("%.2f" % answer).

It didn't matter for any of your tests, but it's good for a Reverse clash to not have any ambiguity in how to solve it, because otherwise you never know if 100% in the tests will translate to 100% on validators.
You're right. I actually made sure that the tests wouldn't have stuff like 17.40 lol. But yeah now it's consistent and all answers are 2 decimal places.
